Dialogue: significantly more attractive.

Dialogue: I'm kidding, I'm kidding, we're still young, Darien. So what's money anyway when everybody's making it, it's all relative. Dialogue: Do you think you're ready?

Dialogue: It's not me I'm worried about...You know Darien, the only reason we haven't slept together is because we both know we will -- and not knowing when was the only surprise left. You owe me, I want you, what else is there...but you, me, the world.  Stop me if I'm going too far.

Dialogue: I love you, baby. Did I tell you that sometime in the last 24 hours?

Dialogue: ...that changes all my plans, I thought you were loaded...

Dialogue: So did I, till I hit 19 and found I had all the royal habits and no throne. Mom got by but I had to go to work just like you. Only the skills I had were shopping and making friends. So...that's why I do what I do, what makes you tick, Buddy?

Speaker: bud
Dialogue: Fear. The fear of being poor I guess, just like you, Darien... But that's all gonna change sweetheart. I'm catching the express...  ... and you're going along for the ride.

Dialogue: ...Bluestar's an unpolished gem, Gordon, right out of the garbage. A half assed management being decimated by a price war they can't win. But the gates at LaGuardia alone can bail us out, it's worth 25 bucks a share if it's worth a dime! They're ripe to fall.

Dialogue: Mixed emotions, Buddy: like Larry Wildman going off a cliff in my new Maserati. Men as smart as myself have got their asses handed to them on a sling with the airlines, fuel could go up, unions are killers...

Dialogue: Yeah aren't you forgetting something Gordon: rule one, capital reserves. This company has $75 million cash in an overfunded pension. That buys us a lot of credibility...  ...and the beauty is you already own close to two percent of this sucker...

Dialogue: Gordon, the insurance people are balking on the logging trucks...

Dialogue: Tell those spineless toads we'll self-insure if they don't write it... You fire 33 vice presidents and nothing changes...  You eating twinkies today, Bud, or are you schtupping some stewardess...

Dialogue: I'm talking to a stockbroker who wants to run an airline. It's gonna take me two years and 2000 headaches to turn Teldar Paper around, what do I need this dink airline for? I'm up to my ass in more nuts than a fruitcake.

Speaker: bud
Dialogue: Gordon, I worked at Bluestar, I know my way around, I have friends there...inside.

Dialogue: What does that mean?

Dialogue: What makes you think you can?

Speaker: bud
Dialogue: I can talk to these people Gordon, they trust me...and my father can be a big help in getting cuts.

Speaker: gekko
Dialogue: So sport, the falcon has heard the falconer...tell me more...

Speaker: bud
Dialogue: Dad, well come on in. Everybody's here. We couldn't start the show without you.

Dialogue: Well I'll be a lousy Republican.

Speaker: darien
Dialogue: I'm Darien Taylor.

Dialogue: Pretty creative. Doesn't look anything like the place my son bought a few months age.

Speaker: darien
Dialogue: Listen, I hope you'll come here often, and under less formal circumstances.

Speaker: bud
Dialogue: Dad, you know Duncan Wilmore, pilot's union, and Toni Carpenter, flight attendants...

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: I met them before you were born.

Speaker: bud
Dialogue: And I'd like to introduce you to Mr. Gekko, and his lawyer, Mr. Salt.

Speaker: gekko
Dialogue: A pleasure to meet you, Mr. Fox.

Speaker: gekko
Dialogue: I'd be proud to have a son like Bud. He's got a great future ahead of him.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: I thought this was an informal meeting. What's he doing here?

Speaker: gekko
Dialogue: Harold, you don't mind strolling around the block a couple hundred times, do you?

Speaker: harold
Dialogue: Of course...

Speaker: darien
Dialogue: ...please help yourselves to some food...

Dialogue: Look, I have no illusions about winning a popularity contest with any of you. I was roasted the other night, and a friend of mine asked-- why are we honoring this man--have we run out of human beings?

Dialogue: With all due respect, Mr. Gekko, what's to prevent you from doing the same thing?

Speaker: gekko
Dialogue: Cause I have a way around all this, a way we can all make money and make this airline profitable again. What do you say we cut to the chase. I'm asking for a modest twenty percent across-the-board wage cut.

Speaker: gekko
Dialogue: And seven more hours a month.

Speaker: carpenter
Dialogue: What kind of time frame are we talking about here?

Speaker: gekko
Dialogue: Give me a year. If we're still losing money, the reductions stand. If however, we move into the black, I return part of the givebacks, salaries go back to present levels, and...  we institute an employee profit sharing program with stock. You'll own part of the airline.

Speaker: wilmore
Dialogue: Are you prepared to put that in writing?

Speaker: gekko
Dialogue: I'll have a letter of agreement drawn up within two days.

Speaker: carpenter
Dialogue: What's your marketing strategy? How do you plan to return us to profitability?

Speaker: gekko
Dialogue: Why don't I give Bud an opportunity to answer that.

Speaker: bud
Dialogue: Thank you Mr. Gekko. First of all I want you to know my door will always be open to you cause I know from my Dad it's you guys that keep Bluestar flying. One -- Modernize. Three -- expand our hubs to Atlanta, North Carolina and Dallas, reorganize all our feeder schedules, think Big -- guys, we're going after the majors!

Speaker: gekko
Dialogue: Cards are on the table. What do you think?

Speaker: wilmore
Dialogue: If you mean what you say, I think we're in the ball park. I'll take it to my people.

Speaker: carpenter
Dialogue: You've sketched some broad strokes. I'd like to see the fine print. But so far so good.

Dialogue: I guess if a man lives long enough, he gets to see everything. And I mean everything. What else do you have in your bag of tricks, Mr. Gekko?

Dialogue: Frankly, Carl, I can't see giving much more. If you have any suggestions I'll be glad to listen.

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: There came into Egypt a Pharoah who did not know.

Speaker: gekko
Dialogue: I beg your pardon. Is that a proverb?

Dialogue: I know what this guy is about-- greed--he's in and out for the buck and he don't take prisoners. He don't give a damn about Northstar or us ...

Speaker: bud
Dialogue: Now, wait a minute, Dad...

Speaker: gekko
Dialogue: Sure. What's worth doing is worth doing for money. It's a bad bargain where nobody gains. And if this deal goes through, we all gain.

Dialogue: 'Course my son did work three summers as a baggage handler and freight loader. With those qualifications, why should I doubt his ability to run an airline?

Speaker: gekko
Dialogue: Fine, if you don't want us, stay with the scum in present management--dedicated to running you and Bluestar into the ground.

Dialogue: Congratulations. You did a great job of embarrassing me in there-- not to mention yourself! Save the "workers of the world unite" speech for next time Dad, I heard it too much growing up. Dialogue: He's got your prick in his back pocket, son, and you're standing naked in the display window of Macy's. He's using you. Only you're too blind to see it.

Dialogue: No, what I see is a jealous old machinist who can't stand that his son's become more successful than himself.

Dialogue: What you see, son, is a man who never measured success by the size of a man's wallet.

Speaker: bud
Dialogue: That's because you never had the guts to go out into the world and stake your claim.

Dialogue: Boy, if that's what you think, I must've really screwed up my job as a father.

Dialogue: I'll be damned that when my men come to me tomorrow morning, wanting to know what's going on, I'm going to lie to them!

Dialogue: And what if you're wrong? What if one day, the sun didn't rise in the East and birds didn't fly South in winter and for once in your life your compass was off? Huh?

Speaker: carl
Dialogue: I don't sleep with no whore and I don't wake up with no whore. That's how I live with myself, Buddy. I don't know how you do.  I hope I'm wrong, I'll let them decide for themselves, that much I promise you.

Dialogue: You sure?

Dialogue: I don't know anything!

Dialogue: Didn't I tell you to knock before you came in here?

Dialogue: Hey the door was open.

Dialogue: Then get out and close it behind you.

Dialogue: You know what you need, buddy buddy--an optorectomy. That's when they cut the nerve that runs from your brain to your rectum--to change that shitty attitude of yours.

Dialogue: Get the hell out!

Dialogue: So what's the problem?

Dialogue: Alright... I just wanna slow down Bud... no more calls for awhile, no lunches... we suspend our business, alright...

Dialogue: Sure Roger, whatever you want, it's cool.

Dialogue: I didn't know we had a meeting schedule for this morning.

Dialogue: I'm sorry, this can't wait.

Dialogue: What the hell do you want?

Dialogue: Last night I read Rudy the story of Winnie the Pooh and the Honey pot. Know what happened: he stuck his nose in that honey pot once too often and got stung.

Dialogue: Maybe you ought to read him Pinocchio. You told me you were going to turn Bluestar around. Not upside down. You used me.

Dialogue: If these people lose their jobs, nowhere to go. My father worked at Bluestar for twenty-four years. I gave 'em my word.

Dialogue: Tell me, Gordon--when does it all end? How many yachts can you waterski behind? How much is enough?

Speaker: bud
Dialogue: How much is enough Gordon?

Speaker: bud
Dialogue: Obviously...

Speaker: gekko

Dialogue: ...I can't make it tonight.

Dialogue: Are you with me Buddy?

Dialogue: I want you with me.

Speaker: bud
Dialogue: I'm with you Gordon...

Speaker: gekko
Dialogue: ...be another minute, Natalie.

Dialogue: This is Gordon Gekko. Now...  I want zip-locked mouths on Bluestar, or I'm gonna personally come down there and rip out your fucking throats!

Speaker: darien
Dialogue: Bud?...What's going on?

Speaker: bud
Dialogue: I've been played like a grand- piano--by the master, Gekko the Great...and today was the big crash. Liquidation sale. He's gonna carve Bluestar into little pieces and sell it all off...

Speaker: darien
Dialogue: I'm sorry. I was afraid something like this could happen.

Speaker: bud
Dialogue: Talk about being bent over the sink of life and being dry humped. I handed it to him on a silver platter. I told my father and those people...

Speaker: darien
Dialogue: Buddy, it's not your fault, and it's not your decision.

Speaker: bud
Dialogue: I'm not gonna let it happen Darien.

Dialogue: Don't cross Gordon. He'll crush you. You've worked hard to get where you are. If Gordon doesn't buy Bluestar someone else will; and who's to say they won't do the same thing.

Dialogue: At least I wouldn't be pulling the trigger.

Dialogue: Are you mad! Why are you doing this! We're so close, the town is going to be ours. Don't throw away your future Bud!

Dialogue: I can stay with the brokerage firm. And you're doing fine. We can survive without Gordon Gekko.

Dialogue: I'm not looking to just survive. I've been doing that all my life.

Dialogue: What the hell's that supposed to mean?

Speaker: darien
Dialogue: That if you make an enemy of Gordon Gekko, I won't be there to stand by you.

Dialogue: You really mean that?  What'd he promise you? To take you public? I guess without Gordon's money and seal of approval, I'm not such a hot investment anymore. You're just the best money can buy, Darien...

Dialogue: You're not exactly pure Bud, you went after Gekko with the same vengeance you went after me. Look in the mirror before...
